title: Kerry Katona's estranged husband George Kay branded 'daft' by judge
title_page: Kerry Katona's estranged husband George Kay branded 'daft' by judge | Daily Mail Online
text:
A judge told Kerry Katona's ex-husband not to be 'daft' when he asked if he could get his haircut near her home - after being ordered by the court to stay away from her.
George Kay, 36, was in court yesterday on charges of assault by beating and possessing a banned weapon, after an alleged row at their home in Crowborough, East Sussex, in September.
The former rugby league player pleaded not guilty and was released until the trial, on the conditions that he is not to contact her and must stay out of Crowborough.
But Kay then asked if he was allowed to go there to get his haircut, to which the judge replied: 'No, that's slightly daft. You can get your hair cut somewhere else.'
George Kay, the estranged husband of Kerry Katona, arrives at Hove Crown Court this morning
Kay was arrested following an alleged row at the couple's home in Crowborough on September 19 after an alleged row.
He was charged by Sussex Police with assault by beating and possessing a banned weapon, relating to a Taser-style instrument which was disguised.
At Hove Crown Court today, Kay, an ex-rugby league player from Warrington, Cheshire, pleaded not guilty to both charges and will stand trial from April 25.
Former I'm A Celebrity Get Me Out of Here and Celebrity Big Brother contestant Katona, who married labourer Kay in 2014, is likely to give evidence in the case.
The alleged attack is said to have taken place just five days after the couple's one-year wedding anniversary.
Katona married ex-rugby league player Kay in 2014 but has revealed they split after his arrest
Since then, three-times married Katona, 35, has announced the couple have split. In an interview with OK! magazine, she said breaking up was 'hard' but 'the right thing to do'.
She said: 'George was with me 24/7. It's like somebody has died. He was my best friend.' But she added: 'There is no going back with George and me.'
Judge David Rennie freed Kay on bail on condition that he does not contact Katona except via an agreed third party, and does not enter Crowborough.
